Award.AwardTitle: Crystal-Based Molecular Modulation for Arbitrary Spatio-Temporal Optical Waveform Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
A technique is being developed for sub-femtosecond pulse generation and sub-cycle pulse shaping. The essence of the technique is the preparation of a macroscopic medium in a coherent superposition-state. This preparation is accomplished by two laser pulses tuned close to a molecular Raman resonance. The resultant molecular motion modulates the input light to produce a wide spectrum of discrete sidebands. Broadband coherent generation in Raman-active crystals is shown, and the capability to control spectral phases of the Raman sidebands in a precise and stable manner is demonstrated. This is the first step toward sub-cycle pulse shaping, which will allow synthesis of waveforms where the electric field is an arbitrary predetermined function of time, not limited to quasi-sinusoidal oscillations. As a result, a direct and precise control of electron trajectories in photoionization and high-order harmonic generation will become possible. In addition, coherent transfer of optical orbital angular momentum in multi-order Raman generation is investigated. The use of singular light beams, such as optical vortices, provides a new degree of freedom for ultrashort pulse manipulation, and will open a possibility for spatio-temporal engineering of sub-cycle pulses.

The broad impact of this research derives not only from the promised discoveries in fundamental science, but also come from a variety of practical applications of the new broad-band Raman source. These applications are: optical coherence tomography, ultrafast spectroscopy, precision metrology, to name a few. In addition, the technique of molecular modulation can be used to generate coherent radiation in the UV and IR spectral regions, where laser sources are not readily available. Eventually, applications to lithography, chemistry, biology, and astronomy may become practical. An important part of this project is the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students. The project provides these students with training in the field of quantum optics and laser physics and will allow them to develop both theoretical and experimental skills which are in high demand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been aimed at developing a light source where the possibility of sub-cycle optical field shaping is combined with transverse beam shaping.  Our technique is based on molecular coherence and termed ‘molecular modulation’. We build upon our recent achievements in coherent broadband generation with sub-picosecond laser excitation in Raman-active crystals. We use a pair of femtosecond laser pulses tuned such that their frequency difference is approximately equal to the Raman frequency, and observe generation of sidebands covering the infrared, visible, and ultraviolet spectral regions. We explore possibilities for spectral phase control across this ultrabroad spectrum, while characterizing synthesized ultrafast waveform by recording a nonlinear spectral interferogram. We use acousto-optic phase adjustments, deformable mirrors, and computer-controlled delay lines that have nanometer precision.  The resultant interferograms, obtained through sideband interaction in various nonlinear crystals, are decoded with phase-retrieval algorithms. In this work, we observe significant pre- and post-pulses; we should be able to reduce these by reducing the frequency spacing between our sidebands. In addition, we use a liquid crystal light modulator for drive (pump and Stokes) beam shaping, and explore its role in nonlinear interactions. In particular, we investigate the transfer of orbital angular momentum among multiple beams involved in a coherent Raman interaction. We shape pump and Stokes beams into optical vortices with various integer values of topological charge, and cross them in a Raman-active crystal to produce multiple Stokes and anti-Stokes sidebands. We measure the resultant vortex charges using a tilted-lens technique. We verify that in every case the generated beams’ topological charges obey a simple relationship, resulting from angular momentum conservation for created and annihilated photons, or equivalently, from phase-matching considerations for multiple interacting beams. These are steps toward production of space- and time-tailored optical fields. In other projects with strong intellectual connection, we demonstrate the efficacy of atomic and molecular coherence effects for coherent Raman spectroscopic detection, sensing, and microscopy applications, as well as study resonant tip-enhanced Raman scattering in the quantum-limit regime. 

Broader impact: The results of our work have been broadly disseminated and presented in well over 20 talks (with about 12 invited and 2 plenary) at various conferences by graduate students, postdocs, and the PI (who also gave several colloquia and seminars). The PI has organized Molecular Modulation sessions at the Physics of Quantum Electronics workshop (Snowbird, Utah) etc., as outlined in his CV, and has participated and presented demonstrations, together with his graduate students, at our Department’s Physics Festival. In addition to his regular teaching load, Sokolov has led a weekly study group on Nonlinear Optics, and served as a faculty advisor to an OSA student chapter. A group of excellent graduate students has been involved in projects under this grant. More details on each person’s contributions to this NSF project have been given in the annual reports to the NSF. Moreover, Alexei Sokolov and his graduate students, Alexandra Zhdanova (5th year graduate student) and Mariia Shutova (4th year graduate student), are actively involved in Texas A&M University outreach activities, such as “Discover, Explore, and Enjoy Physics and Engineering” (DEEP) projects where they lead a team of undergraduates in building demonstrations of interesting physics principles.
